content:
Hi :wave:

The nLab defines a directed graph as a functor

G:X→Set,G: X\to \text{Set},G:X→Set,

where XXX is a category with two objects X0,X1X^0,X^1X0,X1 and two morphisms s,t:X1→X0.s,t: X^1\to X^0.s,t:X1→X0.

Then

DiGraph=[X,Set]\text{DiGraph} = [X,\text{Set}]DiGraph=[X,Set]

is the functor category of directed graphs.

It says this is naturally extended to a functor category [X,C][X,C][X,C], which would be referred to as a "Quiver in CCC".

I'm trying to understand this for some common categories, e.g. "Quiver in Vect\text{Vect}Vect", "Quiver in Alg\text{Alg}Alg", "Quiver in BiMod"\text{BiMod}"BiMod", "Quiver in DGAlg\text{DGAlg}DGAlg", etc.

Starting with [X,Vect][X,\text{Vect}][X,Vect], let

V:X→VectV: X\to\text{Vect}V:X→Vect

with V0=V(X0)V^0 = V(X^0)V0=V(X0) and V1=V(X1)V^1=V(X^1)V1=V(X1) and I'll reuse the labels sss and ttt for source and target maps s,t:V1→V0.s,t: V^1\to V^0.s,t:V1→V0.

First question: Is V1=V0⊗V0V^1 = V^0\otimes V^0V1=V0⊗V0?

A "Quiver in CCC" looks like a special "Span in CCC". Is this a useful way to think of it?

Then this article from John looks interesting (but a bit over my head): Bimodules Versus Spans.

I'd love to understand how a "Quiver in CCC" might relate to bimodules.
A quiver in C is the same as an "endospan" in C. A general span looks like
x←a→yx \leftarrow a \rightarrow yx←a→y
and we call this a span from xxx to yyy . So, by "endospan" I mean a span from some object to itself, like this:
x←a→x x \leftarrow a \rightarrow x x←a→x
But this is just a quiver in C.
Btw, don't say "endospan" unless you're talking to someone who deeply understands category theory: it's not a standard term.
Someone who really knows about this stuff would probably guess what you meant, but don't count on it.
I'd love to understand how a "Quiver in C" might relate to bimodules.
Well, in my article I explain how every object in Setop\mathsf{Set}^{op}Setop is a commutative monoid in Setop\mathsf{Set}^{op}Setop. "Everyone" knows this, but I go a bit further:

We can define bimodules not just for algebras (which are modules in Vect) but for monoids in any category... any category that can have monoids in it. And then a span of sets is the exact same thing as a bimodule in Setop\mathsf{Set}^{op}Setop.
So, in brief: the concept of bimodule makes sense in a large class of categories, called "monoidal categories". And this generalization of bimodule has spans of sets as a special case.
So in particular a quiver of sets (better known to category theorists as a "graph"), which is the same as an endospan of sets, is a special case of an endo-bimodule.
Again, "endo-bimodule" is not a standard term, but I mean an (A,B)(A,B)(A,B)-bimodule where A=BA = BA=B.
There's a lot more to say about all this, but I will spare you and not say anything more.

I'd love to hear more :heart: This is all fascinating stuff :blush:

Thank you :raised_hands:
You think you'd love to hear more, but you said my article was "too advanced" so I think at some point you'll "hit the wall" - I don't want to overdose you.
I'll just say a couple of things. A category is a quiver in Set with extra structure, namely "identity" arrows and the ability to compose arrows.
So a category is a special sort of span in Set.
And this viewpoint turns out to be very powerful: people in the know say "a category is the same as a monoid in Span(Set)".
That's one thing: it takes work to learn this and adopt this viewpoint, but it's very powerful.

Another thing: I've said how every span in Set can be seen as a bimodule in Setop\mathsf{Set}^{\mathrm{op}}Setop; one could ask to generalize this to other categories. It works for all "cartesian" categories - categories with finite products.

One could also wonder if a plain old bimodule of algebras, i.e. a bimodule in (Vect,⊗)(\mathsf{Vect}, \otimes)(Vect,⊗), can be seen as a span somewhere. I don't think so - but if someone knows how to do it, I'd love to hear it.

You think you'd love to hear more, but you said my article was "too advanced"

I see. By "spare" you meant literally "spare me the pain". Sometimes "spare" indicates a perceived lack of disinterest. That definitely isn't the case here, but yeah. I might not yet be able to appreciate. That has never stopped me before though :blush:
I figure it's better to say a bit of stuff you understand than produce a massive wall of text. I actually like being understood - unlike some mathematicians. :upside_down:

I might be going off in the wrong direction, but I have a series of nnn categories AlgObjn\text{AlgObj}_nAlgObjn​ of algebraic objects having successively complex structures with a series of forgetful functors Un:AlgObjn→AlgObjn−1U_n: \text{AlgObj}_n\to\text{AlgObj}_{n-1}Un​:AlgObjn​→AlgObjn−1​ terminating with

U1:AlgObj1→Set.U_1: \text{AlgObj}_1 \to \text{Set}.U1​:AlgObj1​→Set.

For each UnU_nUn​, I'm assuming there is a left adjoint FnF_nFn​

Then, I want to try to understand

[X,AlgObjn][X,\text{AlgObj}_n][X,AlgObjn​]

by successively freely constructing

X→GSet→F1AlgObj1→F2⋯→FnAlgObjnX\overset{G}{\to}\text{Set}\overset{F_1}{\to}\text{AlgObj}_1\overset{F_2}{\to}\cdots\overset{F_n}{\to}\text{AlgObj}_nX→GSet→F1​AlgObj1​→F2​⋯→Fn​AlgObjn​

by incrementally adding structure.

For example, with

X→GSet→F1VectX\overset{G}{\to}\text{Set}\overset{F_1}{\to}\text{Vect}X→GSet→F1​Vect

we end up with two vector spaces V0,V1V^0, V^1V0,V1 and two linear maps s,t:V1→V0.s,t:V^1\to V^0.s,t:V1→V0.

I "think" V1=V0⊗V0V^1 = V^0\otimes V^0V1=V0⊗V0 so that V0V^0V0 is used to contruct V1V^1V1, but then we can continue with

X→GSet→F1Vect→F2GVectX\overset{G}{\to}\text{Set}\overset{F_1}{\to}\text{Vect}\overset{F_2}{\to}\text{GVect}X→GSet→F1​Vect→F2​GVect

of graded vector spaces where Vn=⊗nV0V^n = \otimes^n V^0Vn=⊗nV0.

Ok, but then I get confused because that starts feeling like a span, so maybe I should have started with

X→GSet→F1Span(Vect)X\overset{G}{\to}\text{Set}\overset{F_1}{\to}\text{Span(Vect)}X→GSet→F1​Span(Vect)

instead :thinking:

"Like a record baby :dancer:"
At the end, I want to end up with something like graded Hilbert modules.
